column2: The room was in disorder, the table was overturned, and amid the wreckage of glass and china lay Mark Berwin, with outspread hands--stone dead--stabbed to the heart.
column3: The room was in disorder, the table was overturned, and amid the wreckage of glass and china lay Mark Berwin, with outspread hands-stone dead-stabbed to the heart.

column2: CHAPTER V
column3: CHAPTER five

column2: THE TALK OF THE TOWN
column3: THE TALK OF THE TOWN

column2: Nowadays, events, political, social, and criminal, crowd so closely on one another's heels that what was formerly a nine days' wonder is scarcely marvelled at the same number of minutes.
column3: Nowadays, events, political, social, and criminal, crowd so closely on one another's heels that what was formerly a nine days' wonder is scarcely marvelled at the same number of minutes.

column2: Yet in certain cases episodes of a mysterious or unexpected nature engage the attention of a careless world for a somewhat longer period, and provoke an immense amount of discussion and surmise.
column3: Yet in certain cases episodes of a mysterious or unexpected nature engage the attention of a careless world for a somewhat longer period, and provoke an immense amount of discussion and surmise.

column2: In this category may be placed the crime committed in Geneva Square; for when the extraordinary circumstances of the case became known, much curiosity was manifested regarding the possible criminal and his motive for committing so apparently useless a crime.
column3: In this category may be placed the crime committed in Geneva Square; for when the extraordinary circumstances of the case became known, much curiosity was manifested regarding the possible criminal and his motive for committing so apparently useless a crime.

column2: To add to the wonderment of the public, it came out in the evidence of Lucian Denzil at the inquest that Berwin was not the real name of the victim; so here the authorities were confronted with a three-fold problem.
column3: To add to the wonderment of the public, it came out in the evidence of Lucian Denzil at the inquest that Berwin was not the real name of the victim; so here the authorities were confronted with a three fold problem.

column2: They had first to discover the name of the dead man; second, to learn who it was had so foully murdered him; and third, to find out the reason why the unknown assassin should have slain an apparently harmless man.
column3: They had first to discover the name of the dead man; second, to learn who it was had so foully murdered him; and third, to find out the reason why the unknown assassin should have slain an apparently harmless man.

column2: But these hidden things were not easily brought to light; and the meagre evidence collected by the police failed to do away with any one of the three obstacles--at all events, until after the inquest.
column3: But these hidden things were not easily brought to light; and the meagre evidence collected by the police failed to do away with any one of the three obstacles-at all events, until after the inquest.

column2: When the jury brought in a verdict that the deceased had been violently done to death by some person or persons unknown, the twelve good men and true stated the full extent of knowledge gained by Justice in her futile scramble after clues.
column3: When the jury brought in a verdict that the deceased had been violently done to death by some person or persons unknown, the twelve good men and true stated the full extent of knowledge gained by Justice in her futile scramble after clues.

column2: Berwin--so called--was dead, his assassin had melted into thin air, and the Silent House had added a second legend to its already uncanny reputation.
column3: Berwin-so called-was dead, his assassin had melted into thin air, and the Silent House had added a second legend to its already uncanny reputation.

column2: Formerly it had been simply haunted, now it was also blood-stained, and its last condition was worse than its first.
column3: Formerly it had been simply haunted, now it was also blood stained, and its last condition was worse than its first.

column2: The dead man had been found stabbed to the heart by some long, thin, sharp-pointed instrument which the murderer had taken away with him--or perhaps her, as the sex of the assassin, for obvious reasons, could not be decided.
column3: The dead man had been found stabbed to the heart by some long, thin, sharp pointed instrument which the murderer had taken away with him-or perhaps her, as the sex of the assassin, for obvious reasons, could not be decided.

column2: Mrs. Kebby swore that she had left the deceased sitting over the fire at eight o'clock on Christmas Eve, and that he had then been fairly well, though far from enjoying the best of health.
column3: mrs Kebby swore that she had left the deceased sitting over the fire at eight o'clock on Christmas Eve, and that he had then been fairly well, though far from enjoying the best of health.

column2: When she returned, shortly after nine, on Christmas morning, the man was dead and cold.
column3: When she returned, shortly after nine, on Christmas morning, the man was dead and cold.

column2: Medical aid was called in at the same time as the police were summoned; and the evidence of the doctor who examined the body went to prove that Berwin had been dead at least ten hours; therefore, he must have been assassinated between the hours of eleven and twelve of the previous night.
column3: Medical aid was called in at the same time as the police were summoned; and the evidence of the doctor who examined the body went to prove that Berwin had been dead at least ten hours; therefore, he must have been assassinated between the hours of eleven and twelve of the previous night.

column2: Search was immediately made for the murderer, but no trace could be found of him, nor could it be ascertained how he had entered the house. The doors were all locked, the windows were all barred, and neither at the back nor in the front was there any outlet left open whereby the man--if it was a man who had done the deed--could have escaped.
column3: Search was immediately made for the murderer, but no trace could be found of him, nor could it be ascertained how he had entered the house. The doors were all locked, the windows were all barred, and neither at the back nor in the front was there any outlet left open whereby the man-if it was a man who had done the deed-could have escaped.

column2: Blinders, the policeman on duty at the entrance of the square, gave evidence that he had been on duty there all night, and that although many servants and owners of houses belonging to the square had passed in from their Christmas marketings, yet no stranger had entered.
column3: Blinders, the policeman on duty at the entrance of the square, gave evidence that he had been on duty there all night, and that although many servants and owners of houses belonging to the square had passed in from their Christmas marketings, yet no stranger had entered.

column2: The policeman knew every one, even to the errand-boys of the neighbourhood, who brought parcels of Christmas goods, and in many cases had exchanged greetings with the passers-by; but he was prepared to swear, and, in fact, did swear at the inquest, that no stranger either came into or went out of Geneva Square.
column3: The policeman knew every one, even to the errand boys of the neighbourhood, who brought parcels of Christmas goods, and in many cases had exchanged greetings with the passers by; but he was prepared to swear, and, in fact, did swear at the inquest, that no stranger either came into or went out of Geneva Square.

column2: Also he deposed that when the traffic died away after midnight he had walked round the square, and had looked at every window, including that of No. 13, and had tried every door, also including that of No. 13, only to find that all was safe.
column3: Also he deposed that when the traffic died away after midnight he had walked round the square, and had looked at every window, including that of no thirteen, and had tried every door, also including that of no thirteen, only to find that all was safe.

column2: Blinders declared on oath that he had not on Christmas Eve the slightest suspicion of the horrid tragedy which had taken place in the Silent House during the time he was on duty.
column3: Blinders declared on oath that he had not on Christmas Eve the slightest suspicion of the horrid tragedy which had taken place in the Silent House during the time he was on duty.

column2: When the police took possession of the body and mansion, search was made in bedroom and sitting-room for papers likely to throw light on the identity of the victim, but in vain.
column3: When the police took possession of the body and mansion, search was made in bedroom and sitting room for papers likely to throw light on the identity of the victim, but in vain.

column2: No letters or telegrams, or even writing of any kind, could be discovered; there was no name in the dead man's books, no mark on his clothes, no initials on his linen.
column3: No letters or telegrams, or even writing of any kind, could be discovered; there was no name in the dead man's books, no mark on his clothes, no initials on his linen.

column2: The landlord of the house declared that the deceased had hired the mansion six months before, but had given no references, and as the landlord was glad to let the haunted No. 13 on any terms, he had not insisted upon having them.
column3: The landlord of the house declared that the deceased had hired the mansion six months before, but had given no references, and as the landlord was glad to let the haunted no thirteen on any terms, he had not insisted upon having them.

column2: The deceased, said the landlord, had paid a month's rent in advance in ready money, and at the end of every month he had discharged his liability in the same way.
column3: The deceased, said the landlord, had paid a month's rent in advance in ready money, and at the end of every month he had discharged his liability in the same way.

column2: He gave neither cheque nor notes, but paid always in gold; and beyond the fact that he called himself Mark Berwin, the landlord knew nothing about him.
column3: He gave neither cheque nor notes, but paid always in gold; and beyond the fact that he called himself Mark Berwin, the landlord knew nothing about him.

column2: The firm who had furnished the rooms made almost the same report, quite as meagre and unsatisfactory.
column3: The firm who had furnished the rooms made almost the same report, quite as meagre and unsatisfactory.

column2: Mr. Berwin--so the deceased had given his name--had ordered the furniture, and had paid for it in gold. Altogether, in spite of every effort, the police were obliged to declare themselves beaten.
column3: mr Berwin-so the deceased had given his name-had ordered the furniture, and had paid for it in gold. Altogether, in spite of every effort, the police were obliged to declare themselves beaten.

column2: They could not find out the name of the victim, and therefore were unable to learn his past life, or trace thereby if he had an enemy likely to harm him.
column3: They could not find out the name of the victim, and therefore were unable to learn his past life, or trace thereby if he had an enemy likely to harm him.

column2: Beyond the report given by Lucian of his conversation with the man, which showed that Berwin certainly had some enemy whom he dreaded, there was nothing discovered to show reason for the committal of the crime.
column3: Beyond the report given by Lucian of his conversation with the man, which showed that Berwin certainly had some enemy whom he dreaded, there was nothing discovered to show reason for the committal of the crime.

column2: Berwin--so called--was dead; he was buried under his assumed name, and there, so far as the obtainable evidence went, was an end to the strange tenant of the Silent House.
column3: Berwin-so called-was dead; he was buried under his assumed name, and there, so far as the obtainable evidence went, was an end to the strange tenant of the Silent House.

column2: Gordon Link, the detective charged with the conduct of the case, confessed as much to Denzil.
column3: Gordon Link, the detective charged with the conduct of the case, confessed as much to Denzil.

column2: I do not see the slightest chance of tracing Berwin's past, said he to the barrister.
column3: I do not see the slightest chance of tracing Berwin's past, said he to the barrister.

column2: We are as ignorant about him as we are of the name of the assassin.
column3: We are as ignorant about him as we are of the name of the assassin.

column2: Are you sure there is no clue, Mr. Link?
column3: Are you sure there is no clue, mr Link?

column2: Absolutely none; even the weapon with which the crime was committed cannot be found.
column3: Absolutely none; even the weapon with which the crime was committed cannot be found.

column2: You have searched the house?
column3: You have searched the house?

column2: Every inch of it, and with the result that I have found nothing.	Every inch of it, and with the result that I have found nothing.
column3: true

column2: The surroundings of the case are most mysterious.
column3: The surroundings of the case are most mysterious.

column2: If we do not identify the dead we cannot hope to trace the murderer.
column3: If we do not identify the dead we cannot hope to trace the murderer.

column2: How the wretch got into the house is more than I can discover."
column3: How the wretch got into the house is more than I can discover."

column2: It is strange, admitted Lucian thoughtfully, "yet in some secret way people were in the habit of entering the house, and Berwin knew as much; not only that, but he protected them from curiosity by denying that they even existed."
column3: It is strange, admitted Lucian thoughtfully, "yet in some secret way people were in the habit of entering the house, and Berwin knew as much; not only that, but he protected them from curiosity by denying that they even existed."

column2: I don't quite follow you, Mr. Denzil.
column3: I don't quite follow you, mr Denzil.

column2: I allude to the shadows on the blind, which I saw myself a week before the murder took place.	I allude to the shadows on the blind, which I saw myself a week before the murder took place.
column3: true

column2: They were those of a man and a woman, and must have been cast by bodies of flesh and blood.
column3: They were those of a man and a woman, and must have been cast by bodies of flesh and blood.

column2: Therefore, two people must have been in Berwin's sitting-room on that night; yet when I met Berwin who was absent at the time--he denied that anyone could have entered his house without his knowledge.
column3: Therefore, two people must have been in Berwin's sitting room on that night; yet when I met Berwin who was absent at the time-he denied that anyone could have entered his house without his knowledge.

column2: More, he actually insisted that I should satisfy myself as to the truth of this by examining the house."
column3: More, he actually insisted that I should satisfy myself as to the truth of this by examining the house."

column2: Which you did?
column3: Which you did?

column2: Yes, but found nothing; yet, said Lucian, with an air of conviction, "however the man and woman entered, they were in the house."
column3: Yes, but found nothing; yet, said Lucian, with an air of conviction, "however the man and woman entered, they were in the house."

column2: Then the assassin must have come in by the same way; but where that way can be, or how it can be found, is more than I can say.
column3: Then the assassin must have come in by the same way; but where that way can be, or how it can be found, is more than I can say.

column2: Does the landlord know of any secret passages?
column3: Does the landlord know of any secret passages?

column2: No; I asked him, replied the detective, "but he stated that houses nowadays were not built with secret passages.
column3: No; I asked him, replied the detective, "but he stated that houses nowadays were not built with secret passages.

column2: When Berwin denied that anyone was in the house, was he afraid, Mr. Denzil?"
column3: When Berwin denied that anyone was in the house, was he afraid, mr Denzil?"

column2: Yes, he seemed to be nervous.
column3: Yes, he seemed to be nervous.

column2: And he told you he had enemies?
column3: And he told you he had enemies?

column2: He hinted that there were people who wished to see him dead.	He hinted that there were people who wished to see him dead.
column3: true

column2: From the way he spoke and the language he used I am satisfied that he was hiding from the vengeance of some one."
column3: From the way he spoke and the language he used I am satisfied that he was hiding from the vengeance of some one."

column2: Vengeance! repeated Link, raising his eyebrows.
column3: Vengeance! repeated Link, raising his eyebrows.

column2: Is not that word a trifle melodramatic?
column3: Is not that word a trifle melodramatic?

column2: Perhaps; but to my mind there is more melodrama in actual life than people fancy.	Perhaps; but to my mind there is more melodrama in actual life than people fancy.
column3: true

column2: However, Mr. Link," added Lucian, "I have come to certain conclusions.
column3: However, mr Link," added Lucian, "I have come to certain conclusions.

column2: Firstly, that Berwin was in hiding; secondly, that he saw people secretly who entered in some way we cannot discover; and thirdly, that to solve the problem it will be necessary to look into the past life of the dead man."
column3: Firstly, that Berwin was in hiding; secondly, that he saw people secretly who entered in some way we cannot discover; and thirdly, that to solve the problem it will be necessary to look into the past life of the dead man."

column2: Your third conclusion brings us round to the point whence we started, retorted Link.
column3: Your third conclusion brings us round to the point whence we started, retorted Link.

column2: How am I to discover the man's past?
column3: How am I to discover the man's past?

column2: By learning who he is, and what is his real name.
column3: By learning who he is, and what is his real name.

column2: An easy task, said the detective sarcastically, "considering the meagre material upon which we have to work.
column3: An easy task, said the detective sarcastically, "considering the meagre material upon which we have to work.

column2: And how is the business to be accomplished?"
column3: And how is the business to be accomplished?"

column2: By advertisement.
column3: By advertisement.

column2: Advertisement!
column3: Advertisement!

column2: Yes.	Yes.
column3: true

column2: I wonder the idea did not strike you before, seeing how often it is used in similar cases.
column3: I wonder the idea did not strike you before, seeing how often it is used in similar cases.

column2: Advertise a full description of the man who called himself Berwin, note his physical peculiarities and looks, and circulate such description by means of handbills and newspapers."
column3: Advertise a full description of the man who called himself Berwin, note his physical peculiarities and looks, and circulate such description by means of handbills and newspapers."

column2: Link looked angry, and laughed rather contemptuously, as his professional pride was touched by the fact of being advised by an individual not of his calling.
column3: Link looked angry, and laughed rather contemptuously, as his professional pride was touched by the fact of being advised by an individual not of his calling.

column2: I am not so ignorant of my business as you think, he said sharply. "What you suggest has already been done.
column3: I am not so ignorant of my business as you think, he said sharply. "What you suggest has already been done.

column2: There are handbills describing the appearance of Berwin in every police office in the kingdom."
column3: There are handbills describing the appearance of Berwin in every police office in the kingdom."

column2: In the newspapers, also? asked Lucian, nettled by the detective's tone.
column3: In the newspapers, also? asked Lucian, nettled by the detective's tone.

column2: No; it is not necessary.
column3: No; it is not necessary.

column2: I don't agree with you.	I don't agree with you.
column3: true

column2: Many people in private life are not likely to see your handbills.
column3: Many people in private life are not likely to see your handbills.

column2: I don't pretend to advise, Mr. Link," he added in soothing tones, "but would it not be wise to use the medium of the daily papers?"
column3: I don't pretend to advise, mr Link," he added in soothing tones, "but would it not be wise to use the medium of the daily papers?"

column2: I'll think of it, said Link, too jealous of his dignity to give way at once.
column3: I'll think of it, said Link, too jealous of his dignity to give way at once.

column2: Oh, I quite rely on your discretion, said Denzil hastily.
column3: Oh, I quite rely on your discretion, said Denzil hastily.

column2: You know your own business best.	You know your own business best.
column3: true

column2: But if you succeed in identifying Berwin, will you let me know?"
column3: But if you succeed in identifying Berwin, will you let me know?"

column2: Link looked keenly at the young man.
column3: Link looked keenly at the young man.

column2: Why do you wish to know about the matter? he asked.
column3: Why do you wish to know about the matter? he asked.

column2: Out of simple curiosity.	Out of simple curiosity.
column3: true

column2: The case is so mysterious that I should like to watch you unravel it."
column3: The case is so mysterious that I should like to watch you unravel it."

column2: Well, said Link, rather gratified by this tribute to his power, "I shall indulge your fancy."
column3: Well, said Link, rather gratified by this tribute to his power, "I shall indulge your fancy."

column2: The result of this conversation was that Lucian observed in the newspapers next day an advertisement describing the looks and name, and physical peculiarities of the deceased, with special mention of the loss of the left hand's little finger, and the strange cicatrice on the right cheek.
column3: The result of this conversation was that Lucian observed in the newspapers next day an advertisement describing the looks and name, and physical peculiarities of the deceased, with special mention of the loss of the left hand's little finger, and the strange cicatrice on the right cheek.

column2: Satisfied that the only way to learn the truth had been adopted by the authorities, Lucian impatiently waited for the development of the scheme.
column3: Satisfied that the only way to learn the truth had been adopted by the authorities, Lucian impatiently waited for the development of the scheme.

column2: Within the week he received a visit from the detective.
column3: Within the week he received a visit from the detective.

column2: You were right and I was wrong, Mr. Denzil, admitted Link generously. "The newspapers were of more use than the handbills.
column3: You were right and I was wrong, mr Denzil, admitted Link generously. "The newspapers were of more use than the handbills.

column2: Yesterday I received a letter from a lady who is coming to see me to-morrow at my office.
column3: Yesterday I received a letter from a lady who is coming to see me to morrow at my office.

column2: So if you care to be present at the interview you have only to say so."
column3: So if you care to be present at the interview you have only to say so."

column2: I should like it above all things, said Lucian eagerly.
column3: I should like it above all things, said Lucian eagerly.

column2: Who is the lady?
column3: Who is the lady?

column2: A Mrs. Vrain, who writes from Bath.
column3: A mrs Vrain, who writes from Bath.

column2: Can she identify the dead man?
column3: Can she identify the dead man?

column2: She thinks she can, but, of course, she cannot be certain until she sees the body.	She thinks she can, but, of course, she cannot be certain until she sees the body.
column3: true

column2: Going by the description, however," added Link, "she is inclined to believe that Berwin was her husband."
column3: Going by the description, however," added Link, "she is inclined to believe that Berwin was her husband."

column2: CHAPTER VI
column3: CHAPTER six

column2: MRS. VRAIN'S STORY
column3: mrs VRAIN'S STORY

column2: Denzil was much pleased with the courtesy of the detective Link in permitting him to gain, at first hand, further details of this mysterious case.
column3: Denzil was much pleased with the courtesy of the detective Link in permitting him to gain, at first hand, further details of this mysterious case.

column2: With a natural curiosity, engendered by his short acquaintance with the unfortunate Berwin, he was most anxious to learn why the man had secluded himself from the world in Geneva Square; who were the enemies he hinted at as desirous of his death; and in what manner and for what reason he had met with so barbarous a fate at their hands.
column3: With a natural curiosity, engendered by his short acquaintance with the unfortunate Berwin, he was most anxious to learn why the man had secluded himself from the world in Geneva Square; who were the enemies he hinted at as desirous of his death; and in what manner and for what reason he had met with so barbarous a fate at their hands.

column2: It seemed likely that Mrs. Vrain, who asserted herself to be the wife of the deceased, would be able to answer these questions in full; therefore, he was punctual in keeping the appointment at the office of Link.
column3: It seemed likely that mrs Vrain, who asserted herself to be the wife of the deceased, would be able to answer these questions in full; therefore, he was punctual in keeping the appointment at the office of Link.
